translation.profileDescription: This is my profile page listing out my what, why, and how.

about.title: About
about.withVideo: Watch a one-minute-long video for quick intro.
about.withText: Read a one-minute-long paragraph for quick intro.

faqIntro.intro: Here are some common questions I got as a software engineer. Please take a look before you decide to proceed to work with me :)

q1.question: Q. You did not major in computer science in college. Why changed career path?

q2.question: Q. Are you self-taught?
q2.answer: A. I help and get help online.

q3.question: Q. We need a full stack developer. Are you good at Nextjs?

q4.question: Q. Any other languages than JavaScript?

q5.question: Q. I want to know how you would handle async tasks in Nodejs.

q6.question: Q. Have you ever deployed a smart contract on Mainnet?

coffeeChat.title: Coffee Chat
coffeeChat.description: Discord is a quick way to contact me for online coffee chat. Hit Join Discord button then it will lead to my voice channel. I might be on and off but hit me up when I'm online!

projects.title: Projects
projects.description: A dedicated section for summarizing company works I have engaged. Any type of publicly paid work will be introduced here with filtering sensitive info first.

overview.title: Overview
overview.summary: AOS reward app, Play to earn, Web3 project.
overview.idea: The main idea was simple â€” users play a mobile game and claim an ERC20 token based on playtime.
overview.period: From the service launch (Nov 2023) to end of service (Aug 2025), I worked on this project with the following teammates:
overview.note: The project itself may have been dead (or alive) after I left the company, but the smart contracts I coded still exist on L2 Optimism mainnet.

role.title: Role in the project
role.summary: I was mainly responsible for smart contract and web server, handling onchain transactions with failover.
role.contracts: Check out a list of verified smart contracts I coded during the project.
role.note: Note that these have been all public at the moment of deployment, while upgradeable implementationâ€™s ABI was not disclosed for security reasons.

portfolio.title: Portfolio
portfolio.description: A list of side projects by me.
portfolio.note: Some of them are being maintained, some of them have been shutdown, and some of them are not disclosed here.

dead.title: ğŸ’€ Dead ones
dead.description: These are side projects that I had quit in the middle. Codes exist but not hosted anywhere so no way to show the demo now.

cleverOwls.title: Clever Owls
cleverOwls.description: Membership mobile flutter app for close friends. Created a github repository with rough ideas but never actually coded any.

eduLabs.title: Edu Labs
eduLabs.description: Web3 course selling website. I had prepared a few hand-drafted diagrams and PDF files to sell and coded a website. At the time, I managed to develop a client(`React`)/server(`Fiber`) full stack but didn't really have a clue for infrastructure.

meowRun.title: MeowRun
meowRun.description: Zero install 3D platformer game, hosted on `shimmer.io`, developed with `Unity`. Player is a cat whose target is to safely finish to destination, avoiding dangerous enemies like aliens, snakes, and spiders.

alive.title: ğŸ’» Alive ones
alive.description: Below side projects are relatively newer and maintained to some extent. Code exists, instance deployed, and versioning possible.

minlink.title: Minlink
minlink.description: Lightweight stable coin pegging watcher. Target to check coins on ethereum mainnet with custom thresholds.

hexbook.title: Hexbook
hexbook.description: QR code generator for Cryptocurrency tipping. Target to issue a simple invoice with `Ether` and `USDT`.

ricktcalWorldcup.title: Ricktcal Worldcup
ricktcalWorldcup.description: Signature-based voting dapp for mobile game `Trickcal:Chibi Go`. Vote for one's favorite Character and earn web3 rewards in return.

owlly.title: Owlly
owlly.description: `When did .env value get updated?`, `Who updated this?`. Sometimes we miss important secret updates while coding at work, so I made this desktop app to notify the updates to teammates.

portfolio.cta: Let's take a close look at them

intro.title: Blog | Introduction
intro.author: by Jake Sung

paragraphs.p1: When random thoughts hit me at midnight, I felt there should be a way to express those somewhere.
paragraphs.p2: It would be hard to say I'm at the top of my career, at all, but throughout the journey I happened to have my own view towards certain topics.

questions: Do you need a CS degree to be a software engineer?
Do I rent monthly or Jeonse (Key money deposit)?
How much saving should I keep monthly? Or just spend every penny?
When should I quit 9 to 5? Or, should I just do forever till retirement?
Is college useless when getting a job?
intro.closing: So topics and tones will be quite random and raw as I just pour them out online without second thoughts.

hire.title: Blog | Hire
hire.author: by Jake Sung

paragraphs.p1: Sometimes I think hiring blockchain developers is extremely difficult. Not that hiring is ever easy anywhere, but recruiters in this field seem to struggle more than usual. Maybe itâ€™s because proper evaluation is tricky.
paragraphs.p2: The CTOs at companies where I was lucky enough to get interview opportunities all said the same thing: hiring in Web3 is extremely difficult. Looking at the blockchain industry, junior blockchain developers are like unicorns, and most people switch to blockchain after 5 to 7 years of experience. Even then, many get disappointed and pivot entirely to AI, or even if they donâ€™t, the company ends up failing.
paragraphs.p3: I tend to apply to companies I like even if my experience level doesnâ€™t match, and CTOs often didnâ€™t reject me immediately. Instead, they would get to know me and put me in the talent pool, hinting that I should gain more experience and come back.
paragraphs.p4: And I understand why juniors are discouraged. Thereâ€™s just too much to do and too much to learn. Iâ€™m doing it myself, but I wouldnâ€™t particularly recommend it to a newcomer. Itâ€™s kind of like cigarettes. Iâ€™ve seen backend developers give up after I passionately explained things with diagrams because it was just too complicated, and then quietly return to the development they were doing before.
paragraphs.p5: So the hiring pool is extremely narrow, and finding and validating good talent feels very difficult. It feels like veterans just do what veterans have always done. As a result, teams on the ground are dying due to lack of people, while job seekers are dying because there are no positions. Meanwhile, strict government regulations make running a blockchain company or startup very high-risk. Most set up overseas entities in places like Singapore and operate separately from the Korean branch to avoid legal risks.
paragraphs.p6: Hiring developers is already difficult, and under these conditions, the difficulty only increases. Sometimes you go through all the trouble to hire someone who turns out to be a poor fit, and other times you randomly get a good one. You canâ€™t just comfortably hire senior developers. From what Iâ€™ve seen, once a blockchain developer exceeds seven years of experience, you have to offer over 100 million KRW annually. In other words, itâ€™s expensive. There are talks of SK Hynix offering eight-figure incentives in 2025, but isnâ€™t a 100 million KRW contract salary still considered cheap? Not everyone works at a large corporation, after all.

hire.closing: Itâ€™s a really tough industry. Both hiring and actual service development are difficult. Still, if you decide to do it, the reason matters. It really matters.
